document.masterDocTitle: Revision of subgenera of Stenichnus Thomson, with review of Australo-Pacific species (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of subgenera of Stenichnus Thomson, with review of Australo-Pacific species (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–4. Examples of dorsal (1, 2, 4) and lateral (3) habitus of
Stenichnus
s. str.
Stenichnus bicolor (Denny)
(1);
S. collaris (Müller & Kunze)
(2, 3);
S. totoro Jałoszyński
(4).

FIGURES 5–8.
Stenichnus
(s. str.)
collaris (Müller & Kunze)
. Head in dorsal (5), anterior (6), left lateral (7) and ventral (8) views. Abbreviations: as, antennal socket; ce, compound eye; cl, clypeus; fcg, fronto-clypeal groove; fo, foramen occipitale; fr, frons; gen, gena; gp, gular plate; gs, gular suture; h, hypostoma; hr, hypostomal ridge; lb, labrum; lss, lateral suture of submentum; md, mandible; mn, mentum; mx, maxilla; mxp, maxillary palp; mxp2–4, maxillary palpomere II–IV; nr, neck region; occ, occipital constriction; pmn, prementum; smn, submentum; tm, temple; vt, vertex.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Antennae (
Figs. 1 –4
, 7 ) slender, gradually thickening towards apices, antennomeres moderately compactly assembled, sparsely covered with suberect to erect setae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 9–17.
Stenichnus
(s. str.)
collaris (Müller & Kunze)
. Mouthparts in dorsal view (9), epipharynx in ventral view (10), base of right mandible in dorsal view (11), mandibles and labrum in ventral view (12), apical part of left mandible in dorsal view (13), maxillae and hypopharynx in dorsal view (14), distal part of right maxillary palp in dorsal view (15), labium and maxillae in ventral view (16), and prementum in anterior view (17). Abbreviations: bp, basal pouch of mandible; bst, basistipes; cd, cardo; cl, clypeus; eph, epipharynx; fcg, fronto-clypeal groove; fr, frons; gal, galea; gl; glandular opening; hph, hypopharynx; lac, lacinia; lb, labrum; ld, labial disc; llh, lateral lobe of hypopharynx; lp1–3, labial palpomere I–III; md, mandible; mn, mentum; ms, marginal sensilla; mst, mesostipes; mv, marginal velum of labrum; mxp1–4, maxillary palpomere I–IV; pmn, prementum; ppf, palpifer; smn, submentum; tr, trichia.

FIGURES 18–21.
Stenichnus
(s. str.)
collaris (Müller & Kunze)
. Prothorax in dorsal (18, 19), left lateral (20) and ventral (21) views. Abbreviations: bf, ante-basal pronotal fovea; bs, basisternal part of prosternum; hy, hypomeron; nss, notosternal suture; pcc, procoxal cavity; pcs, procoxal socket; pn, pronotum; psc, prosternal carina.

FIGURES 22–28.
Stenichnus
(s. str.)
collaris (Müller & Kunze)
. Mesothorax in dorsal view (22), mesothorax in ventral view (23–26), meso- and metathorax in dorsal view (27), metathorax in dorsal view (28). Abbreviations: ai, asetose impression of mesoventrite; aest2, mesanepisternum; aest3, metanepisternum; alc, alacrista; amc, anterior marginal carina of mesocoxal cavity; anp, anterior notal process; ap, apodema; ar, anterior ridge; bef, basal elytral fovea; el, elytron; mcp, mesocoxal projection; mm, median membranous area; mscc, mesocoxal cavity; mscs, mesocoxal socket; msfa, mesofurcal arm; msff, mesofurcal fovea; msvp, mesoventral intercoxal process; mtap, metaventral anterior process; pl, posterior lobe of mesocoxal projection; pnp, posterior notal process; pre, prepectus; prsc3, metaprescutum; psn3, metapostnotum; sc2, mesoscutellum; sc3, metascutum; si, setose impression of mesoventrite; scl2, mesoscutellum; sss, scutoscutellar suture; v3, metaventrite; wb, wing base.

FIGURES 29–31.
Stenichnus
(s. str.)
collaris (Müller & Kunze)
. Pterothorax in ventral view (29), pterothorax and abdomen in left lateral view (30), ventral internal part of pterothorax in dorsal view (31). Abbreviations: aest2, mesanapisternum; aest3, metanepisternum; ai, asetose impression of mesoventrite; amc, anterior marginal carina of mesocoxal cavity; ar, anterior ridge; cx3, metacoxa; epm2, mesepimeron; epm3, metepimeron; fe3, metafemur; mcp, mesocoxal projection; mscc, mesocoxal cavity; msfa, mesofurcal arm; msvp, mesoventral intercoxal process; mtap, metaventral anterior process; mtfa, metafurcal arm; mtfs, metafurcal stem; mtvp, metaventral intercoxal process; pre, prepectus; si, setose impression of mesoventrite; st3–6, abdominal sternite III–VI; tr3, metatrochanter; v2, mesoventrite; v3, metaventrite.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Elytra (
Figs. 1 –4
, 27 ) oval, with rounded apices; humeri without denticle and with variously large, but distinct humeral callus; sub-humeral lines or carinae absent; elytral base with one moderately large, deep circular and asetose basal fovea (
Fig. 27
; bef ) and visible only in transparent mounts trace of another fovea located close to humerus. Metathoracic wings (not shown) about twice as long as elytra, with posterior margin bearing dense fringe of long setae; venation highly reduced and homology of few indistinct veins visible only in basal part of wing difficult to interpret. Legs (
Figs. 1–4
) moderately long and slender, without special characters except for modifications in males of some species: profemora with angulate or rounded dorsal expansion, in some cases strongly flattened laterally; and (less frequently) metatibiae with a denticle or tooth-like projection.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 32–37.
Stenichnus
(s. str.)
collaris (Müller & Kunze)
. Abdomen in ventral (32) and dorsal (33) views, sternite IX of male in ventral view (34), tergites IX and X of male in dorsal view (35), ovipositor in dorsal view (36) and spermatheca (37). Abbreviations: ds, ductus spermathecae; iag, insertion of accessory gland; pg, pygidium; ppr, paraproct; prc, proctiger; prpg, propygidium; st3–8, abdominal sternite III–VIII; st9, abdominal sternite IX; t9–10, abdominal tergite IX–X; vf, valvifer.

FIGURES 38–44.
Stenichnus
(s. str.)
collaris (Müller & Kunze)
. Aedeagus in ventral (38), lateral (39, 43), dorsal (40), ventroapical (41), and apical (42) views, and apex of paramere (44). Abbreviations: adw, apex of dorsal wall; bo, basal orifice; cp, copulatory piece; dw, dorsal wall; end, endophallus; lw, lateral wall; ma, membranous area; mdp, meso-dorsal projection; mvp, meso-ventral projection; pm, paramere; vp, ventral projection; vw, ventral wall.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Most of Palaearctic species of
Stenichnus
can be easily identified as belonging to this genus already on the basis of the general body shape and especially shapes of the head and pronotum, clearly different than in any other genus of Cyrtoscydmini that occurs in this large area. However, in other regions some genera may be highly similar to
Stenichnus
and it is necessary to examine the entire set of diagnostic characters to confirm determinations.
Stenichnus
seems to be most similar to Nearctic
Brachycepsis Brendel, 1889
, a taxon previously treated as a subgenus of
Stenichnus
(elevated to a genus rank by Franz ( 1985 )). Major differences between
Stenichnus
and
Brachycepsis
can be found in the shape of mandibles (falciform in
Stenichnus
vs. subtriangular with a small mesal tooth in
Brachycepsis
); in the structure of prosternum (with fine intercoxal carina in
Stenichnus
vs. with a short, subtriangular intercoxal process in
Brachycepsis
); in asetose impressions on the mesoventrite (separated in middle in
Stenichnus
vs. fused in middle in
Brachycepsis
); and in the metaventral intercoxal process (short and broad in
Stenichnus
vs. long and narrow in
Brachycepsis
). It remains to be studied whether
Brachycepsis
have the labial discs characteristic of
Stenichnus
; this character is nearly impossible to notice in intact specimens in dry or transparent preparations, and a SEM study is required to analyze the structure of labium using specimens with the prementum exposed or on isolated mouthparts. For this reason, having only unique type specimens of most of the taxa treated below, with the labium in most cases concealed by maxillae and mandibles, in the present study the labial discs were not used to re-classify the subgenera of
Stenichnus
. The labial discs within Cyrtoscydmini may be in fact broadly distributed among genera that potentially share a common ancestor with
Stenichnus
. Other characters, both differences and similarities, are used to clarify the taxonomic status of taxa treated herein.
